SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: To investigate whether epigenotyping of patients with isolated hemihyperplasia (IH) can, analogous to genetic screening of patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, be used for the prediction of tumor risk and tumor type of individual patients
STUDY DESIGN: Methylation analysis of H19 and KCNQ1OT1 of 73 patients
Questionnaires were sent to referring clinicians
RESULTS: In 75% of the clinically confirmed patients with IH no epigenetic defect was detected
Paternal uniparental disomy was found in 15%, demethylation of KCNQ1OT1 in only 6%, and hypermethylation of H19 in 3% of isolated hemihyperplasia cases
Ten percent of the patients with IH had development of a childhood tumor associated with paternal uniparental disomy (2/8) or no methylation defect (2/30)
No genetic defect was detected in 10 of 14 additional patients with cancer with IH
In these latter patients, a methylation defect of H19 was seen 3 times and a paternal uniparental disomy once
CONCLUSIONS: Aberrant methylation of the 11p15 region is not common in patients with IH and can at present not be used for tumor risk determination
